ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: Really learned a lot about the culture, how to speak the language, and about Indonesian society. My ability to speak Indonesian was greatly enhanced this semester.
Learned so much about Indonesian language and culture.
Leaned a ton of Indonesian and a lot about their culture

This was the most intense but rewarding semester of Indonesian thus far. After some time away the class was forced to pick up quickly and the standards were high. I learnt plenty about the culture and the language. There was a lot of speaking involved which is highly practical and forces quick uptake of the language.

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments: One strength is the family culture Bu Dinny develops within her class. Only weakness or need for improvement is the need for a more detailed syllabus.
Strength, the professor. She is very passionate about the course and teaching about the culture

No real weaknesses - Bu runs a really engaging class. The class atmosphere is great, there is never a dull class. The only thing I think we could do slightly more on is grammar constructs, but we definitely did more on it than other levels I have taken. It is hard though to fit in with the major emphasis on speaking (which is so so valuable).

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: Definitely. Have really learned a lot about Indonesian and have the ability to truly have a detailed conversation in the language.
Absolutely. The SEAS department is unbelievable and filled with amazing professors who bring in even better teaching assistants
Yes absolutely. You learn a lot and the language is a very widely spoken.
